Scalable Multi-Database Privacy-Preserving Record Linkage using Counting Bloom Filters

Dinusha Vatsalan    Peter Christen    and Erhard Rahm†



Research School of Computer Science, The Australian National University Canberra ACT 0200, Australia †Universita¨¨a\ddot{\mbox{a}}t Leipzig, Institut fu¨¨u\ddot{\mbox{u}}r Informatik, 04109, Leipzig, Germany {dinusha.vatsalan, peter.christen}@anu.edu.au,†rahm@informatik.uni-leipzig.de
Abstract

Privacy-preserving record linkage (PPRL) aims at integrating sensitive information from multiple disparate databases of different organizations. PPRL approaches are increasingly required in real-world application areas such as healthcare, national security, and business. Previous approaches have mostly focused on linking only two databases as well as the use of a dedicated linkage unit. Scaling PPRL to more databases (multi-party PPRL) is an open challenge since privacy threats as well as the computation and communication costs for record linkage increase significantly with the number of databases. We thus propose the use of a new encoding method of sensitive data based on Counting Bloom Filters (CBF) to improve privacy for multi-party PPRL. We also investigate optimizations to reduce communication and computation costs for CBF-based multi-party PPRL with and without the use of a dedicated linkage unit. Empirical evaluations conducted with real datasets show the viability of the proposed approaches and demonstrate their scalability, linkage quality, and privacy protection.

keywords:
Record linkage, similarity, privacy, multi-party, communication patterns, secure summation

1 Introduction

A wide range of real-world applications, including in healthcare, government services, crime and fraud detection, national security, and businesses, require person-related data from multiple sources held by different organizations to be integrated or linked. Integrated data can then be used for data mining and analytics to empower efficient and quality decision making with rich data. Integrating data helps improving the quality of data by identifying and resolving conflicts in data values, enriching data with additional detailed information, and dealing with missing values [2].

The analysis and mining of data integrated across organizations can be used, for example, in health outbreak systems that allow the early detection of infectious diseases before they spread widely around a country or even worldwide. Such an application requires data to be integrated across several sources, including human health data, travel data, consumed drug data, and even animal health data [6]. A second contemporary motivating example is national security applications that integrate data from law enforcement agencies, Internet service providers, businesses, as well as financial institutions to enable the accurate identification of crime and fraud, or of terrorism suspects [25].

In the absence of unique entity identifiers in the databases that are to be linked, personal identifying attributes (such as names and addresses) need to be used for the linkage. Known as quasi-identifiers (QIDs) [41], such attribute values are in general assumed to be sufficiently well correlated with entities to allow accurate linkage. Using such personal information across different organizations, however, often leads to privacy and confidentiality concerns. This problem has been addressed through the development of ‘privacy-preserving record linkage’ (PPRL) [43] techniques. PPRL aims to conduct linkage using only masked (encoded) QIDs without requiring any sensitive or confidential information to be exchanged and revealed between the organizations involved in the linkage. Generally, masking is conducted on QIDs to transform the original values such that a specific functional relationship exists between the original and the masked values [41]. While there have been many different approaches proposed for PPRL (as reviewed in [43]), most work thus far has concentrated on linking records from only two sources (or parties). As the healthcare and national security examples described above show, linking data from several sources is however commonly required in practical applications.

The drawback of the small number of existing PPRL solutions that can link data from multiple parties is that either (1) they only support exact matching (which classifies sets of records as matches if their masked QIDs are exactly the same and as non-matches otherwise) [14, 17] or (2) they are applicable to QIDs of categorical data only [12, 22]. However, in many PPRL applications QIDs of string data, such as names and addresses, are required. These QIDs often contain errors and variations which necessitates the use of approximate comparison functions (that are computationally expensive in terms of the number of comparisons) for comparing QIDs. In this paper, we tackle the multi-party PPRL problem by developing an efficient privacy-preserving approach for approximate matching of (masked) QIDs of string data from multiple records.

We propose the use of Counting Bloom Filter (CBF) encoding, which is a variation of Bloom filter (BF) encoding [43], to enable efficient and approximate privacy-preserving linkage of multiple databases. BFs are bit vectors into which values are hash-mapped using hash functions (as we describe in Section 2.1). CBFs, on the other hand, are integer vectors that contain count values in each position. Multiple BFs can be summarized as a single CBF using the vector addition operation between BFs. Previous BF encoding-based PPRL approaches [8, 33] suggest using a linkage unit (L​U𝐿𝑈LU), which is a dedicated external party that can perform linkage by comparing candidate record sets (masked into BFs) from all database owners and calculating their similarities to classify them as matches or non-matches. Our hypothesis is that, rather than sending BFs from all parties to a linkage unit (L​U𝐿𝑈LU) to calculate their similarity, a single CBF for each candidate record set generated over p𝑝p parties can be used to calculate their similarity, as illustrated in Figure 1 (left for BFs and right for CBFs). Since CBFs contain only the summary information (count values) of multiple records in their positions rather than the actual individual bit values of a single record as in BFs, they provide increased privacy compared to BFs, as we discuss in Section 6. To the best of our knowledge, this privacy aspect of CBFs has so far not been utilized in PPRL.

An additional challenge with multi-party PPRL is that complexity increases significantly with multiple parties in terms of both computational efforts and communication volume. A basic approach would be to send all masked records from all p𝑝p parties to a L​U𝐿𝑈LU that can calculate pair-wise similarities between masked records, which is of O​(p2⋅n2)𝑂⋅superscript𝑝2superscript𝑛2O(p^{2}\cdot n^{2}) complexity, where n𝑛n is the size of databases assuming all databases are of equal size. However, identifying a matching set of records from all p𝑝p parties is not possible with such a basic pair-wise comparison approach. On the other hand, the number of naïve (all-to-all) comparisons between records required across all p𝑝p databases (𝐃1subscript𝐃1\mathbf{D}_{1}, 𝐃2subscript𝐃2\mathbf{D}_{2}, ⋯⋯\cdots, 𝐃psubscript𝐃𝑝\mathbf{D}_{p}) is equal to the product of the size of the databases (i.e. n×n×⋯​n=np𝑛𝑛⋯𝑛superscript𝑛𝑝n\times n\times\cdots n=n^{p}). Addressing this complexity challenge, two-step algorithms have been developed where in the first step a private indexing/blocking technique is used to reduce the number of candidate record sets from npsuperscript𝑛𝑝n^{p} to b⋅np/bp⋅𝑏superscript𝑛𝑝superscript𝑏𝑝b\cdot n^{p}/b^{p}, assuming b𝑏b blocks of equal size. In the second step only these candidate record pairs have to be compared and classified [43]. Compared to the quadratic number of record pairs when linking only two databases (O​(n2)𝑂superscript𝑛2O(n^{2})), in multi-party PPRL the number of candidate record sets increases exponentially with the number of parties (O​(np)𝑂superscript𝑛𝑝O(n^{p})), and thus using existing private blocking techniques would not sufficiently reduce the number of comparisons, as has been empirically studied in several recent approaches [26, 27, 39].

Figure 1 overviews the naïve computation and communication of (masked) candidate record sets from multiple parties (p=4𝑝4p=4) using a L​U𝐿𝑈LU. Independent of the used masking function (BFs in the left figure and CBFs in the right figure) and the communication pattern (direct one-to-one communication between each party and the L​U𝐿𝑈LU in the left figure and ring-based communication among the parties in the right figure, as will be described in Section 2), the naïve approach results in exponential complexity. Efficient communication patterns and advanced filtering approaches for multi-party PPRL therefore need to be developed in order to reduce the potentially huge number of comparisons. Moreover, with multiple parties the privacy risk of collusion increases, where a sub-set of parties collude among them in order to learn about another party’s (or sub-set of parties’) private data. Both examples for the naïve method described in Figure 1 are highly susceptible to collusion.

In order to overcome these scalability and privacy challenges of multi-party PPRL, we introduce two efficient CBF-based communication patterns that either use a L​U𝐿𝑈LU or operate symmetrically without a L​U𝐿𝑈LU (where a trusted external party is not available to act as a L​U𝐿𝑈LU). The proposed approaches can significantly reduce the number of comparisons required between records in contrast to the naïve all-to-all comparisons, and thereby improve the scalability while also improving the privacy (reducing the likelihood of collusions) by arranging parties into several groups and by distributing computations among parties.

Contributions: Our contributions in this paper are: (1) a novel multi-party PPRL protocol based on CBFs and secure summation for efficient, approximate, and private linkage; (2) two variations of extended secure summation protocols for improved privacy against collusion among the data base owners: (a) homomorphic encryption-based and (b) salting-based (using random seed integers); (3) two efficient communication patterns (with and without a L​U𝐿𝑈LU) for reducing the comparison space and risk of collusion between parties and thereby improving scalability and privacy, respectively, in multi-party PPRL; (4) an analysis of the protocol in terms of the three properties of PPRL: scalability (complexity), linkage quality, and privacy; and (5) an empirical evaluation and comparison of our protocol with two baseline approaches using large North Carolina Voter Registration (NCVR) [4] datasets.

Outline: In the following section we describe the preliminaries. In Section 3 we propose our protocol for multi-party PPRL based on CBFs and secure summation, where in Section 4 we we propose two extended secure summation protocols to improve privacy of our approach, and in Section 5 we introduce two efficient communication patterns to improve scalability and privacy. We analyze our protocol in terms of complexity, linkage quality, and privacy in Section 6, and in Section 7 we conduct an empirical study on the NCVR datasets to validate these analyses. We provide a review of related work in Section 8. Finally, we summarize and discuss future research directions in Section 9.

2 Preliminary concepts and building blocks

In this section, we define the problem of multi-party PPRL and explain how CBFs can be used for efficiently calculating similarities (approximate matching) of QID values between a set of multiple (two or more) records (held by different parties) in PPRL.

We assume p𝑝p database owners P1subscript𝑃1P_{1}, P2subscript𝑃2P_{2}, ⋯⋯\cdots, Ppsubscript𝑃𝑝P_{p} with their respective databases 𝐃1subscript𝐃1\mathbf{D}_{1}, 𝐃2subscript𝐃2\mathbf{D}_{2}, ⋯⋯\cdots, 𝐃psubscript𝐃𝑝\mathbf{D}_{p} (containing sensitive or confidential identifying information) participate in the process under the honest-but-curious (HBC) [43]. In the HBC model, parties are assumed to follow the protocol without deviating or sending false information while being curious to learn about other parties’ data. However, the HBC model does not assume that the parties do not collude among them to learn about other parties’ data [19]. We quantify the risk of collusion in multi-party PPRL and the reduction of risk by our communication patterns in Section 6.2. We also assume a set of QID attributes A𝐴A, which will be used for the linkage, is common to all these databases. We formally define the problem of PPRL of multiple databases as follows.

Definition 2.1

Multi-party PPRL: Assume P1,…,PpsubscriptP1…subscriptPpP_{1},\ldots,P_{p} are the ppp owners (parties) of the databases 𝐃1,…,𝐃psubscript𝐃1…subscript𝐃p\mathbf{D}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{D}_{p}, respectively. They wish to determine which of their records R1,i∈𝐃1subscriptR1isubscript𝐃1R_{1,i}\in\mathbf{D}_{1}, R2,j∈𝐃2subscriptR2jsubscript𝐃2R_{2,j}\in\mathbf{D}_{2}, ……\ldots, Rp,k∈𝐃psubscriptRpksubscript𝐃pR_{p,k}\in\mathbf{D}_{p} match based on the (masked) QIDs of these records according to a decision model C(R1,iC(R_{1,i},R2,jsubscriptR2jR_{2,j}, ……\ldots, Rp,k)R_{p,k}) that classifies record sets (R1,i(R_{1,i},R2,jsubscriptR2jR_{2,j}, ……\ldots, Rp,k)R_{p,k}) into one of the two classes 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{M} of matches and 𝐔𝐔\mathbf{U} of non-matches. Assuming the HBC adversary model, parties P1,…,PpsubscriptP1…subscriptPpP_{1},\ldots,P_{p} are honest, in that they follow the linkage protocol steps, while they do not wish to reveal their actual records R1,i,…,Rp,ksubscriptR1i…subscriptRpk{R}_{1,i},\ldots,{R}_{p,k} with any other party. They however are prepared to disclose to each other, or to an external party, the actual values of some selected attributes of the record sets that are in class 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{M} to allow analysis.

Masking functions used for privacy-preserving algorithms can be categorized into two: cryptographic-based secure multi-party computation (SMC) techniques and perturbation-based techniques [41]. The former approach is generally more expensive with regard to the computation and communication complexities though it provides strong privacy guarantees and high accuracy [18]. The latter uses efficient techniques and, as opposed to SMC techniques, these techniques aim to hide (mask) information about the original values (to preserve privacy) while still allowing to perform approximate matching between the masked values using the functional relationship between original and masked data.

We propose an efficient protocol for multi-party PPRL using perturbation-based masking. In this section, we describe the four building blocks of our protocol, and in Section 3 we present our algorithm in detail. In the following two sections we assume a linkage unit (L​U𝐿𝑈LU) is available to conduct the linkage, and in Section 5 we propose a variation where a L​U𝐿𝑈LU is not required to conduct the linkage using our protocol.

2.1 Bloom filter encoding

Bloom filter (BF) encoding has been used as an efficient masking (encoding) technique in several PPRL solutions [9, 17, 26, 34, 35, 38, 39, 40]. A BF bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} is a bit array data structure of length l𝑙l bits where all bits are initially set to 00. k𝑘k independent hash functions, h1,h2,…,hksubscriptℎ1subscriptℎ2…subscriptℎ𝑘h_{1},h_{2},\ldots,h_{k}, each with range 1,…​l1…𝑙1,\ldots l, are used to map each of the elements s𝑠s in a set S𝑆S into the BF by setting the bit positions hj​(s)subscriptℎ𝑗𝑠h_{j}(s) with 1≤j≤k1𝑗𝑘1\leq j\leq k to 111.

Schnell et al. [34] were the first to propose a method for approximate matching in PPRL of two databases using BFs. In their work, as in our protocol, the character q𝑞q-grams (sub-strings of length q𝑞q) of QID values in A𝐴A of each record in the databases to be linked are hash-mapped into a BF using k𝑘k independent hash functions. This method of BF encoding is known as Cryptographic Long term Key (CLK) encoding [34].

These BFs are then either sent to a L​U𝐿𝑈LU that calculates the similarity of pairs of BFs, as suggested by Schnell et al. [34] and Durham et al. [9], or they are partially exchanged among the database owners to distributively calculate the similarities of BF pairs/sets, as proposed by Lai et al. [17] and Vatsalan and Christen for two-party [38] and multi-party [39, 40] approaches. Figure 2(a) illustrates the encoding of bigrams (q=2𝑞2q=2) of two QID values ‘peter’ and ‘pete’ into l=14𝑙14l=14 bits long BFs using k=2𝑘2k=2 hash functions.

2.2 Dice coefficient

Any set-based similarity function (such as overlap, Jaccard, and Dice coefficient) can be used to calculate the similarity of pairs or sets of (multiple) BFs. The Dice coefficient has been used for matching of BFs since it is insensitive to many matching zeros (bit positions to which no q𝑞q-grams are hash-mapped) in long BFs [34]. In future, we aim to investigate how other approximate string comparison functions, such as edit distance [30] and Jaro and Winkler [10, 45], can be extended to calculate the similarity of more than two values.

Definition 2.2

We define the Dice coefficient similarity of p𝑝p BFs (b1,⋯,bpsubscript𝑏1⋯subscript𝑏𝑝b_{1},\cdots,b_{p}) as:

D​i​c​e​_​s​i​m​(b1,⋯,bp)𝐷𝑖𝑐𝑒_𝑠𝑖𝑚subscript𝑏1⋯subscript𝑏𝑝\displaystyle Dice\_sim(b_{1},\cdots,b_{p}) =\displaystyle= p×z∑i=1pxi𝑝𝑧superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑥𝑖\displaystyle\frac{p\times z}{\sum_{i=1}^{p}x_{i}} (1)

where z𝑧z is the number of common bit positions that are set to 111 in all p𝑝p BFs (common 111-bits), and xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} is the number of bit positions set to 111 in bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} (111-bits), 1≤i≤p1𝑖𝑝1\leq i\leq p.

Figure 2(a) illustrates the Dice coefficient similarity calculation of the two QID values ‘peter’ and ‘pete’ masked into BFs.

2.3 Secure summation

A secure summation protocol [7] can be used to securely sum the input values of multiple parties (p≥3𝑝3p\geq 3), such that no party learns the individual values of other parties, but only the summed value. The input can either be a single numeric value or a vector of numeric values. For example, p𝑝p numeric values (v1,v2,⋯,vpsubscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2⋯subscript𝑣𝑝v_{1},v_{2},\cdots,v_{p}) can be securely summed by using a random numeric value r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} which is sent by a L​U𝐿𝑈LU. The first party P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} that receives r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} calculates the summation of r′+v1superscript𝑟′subscript𝑣1r^{\prime}+v_{1} and sends to P2subscript𝑃2P_{2}. This process is repeated until the last party sends r′+v+1+v2+⋯+vpsuperscript𝑟′𝑣1subscript𝑣2⋯subscript𝑣𝑝r^{\prime}+v+1+v_{2}+\cdots+v_{p} to the L​U𝐿𝑈LU which then subtracts r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} from the summed value to calculate the summation of p𝑝p values. The protocol employs a ring-based communication pattern over all parties which allows the L​U𝐿𝑈LU to learn the final values (∑i=1pvisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑣𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{p}v_{i}) but no party will learn the values visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} of the other parties. This basic secure summation (BSS) protocol is susceptible to collusion risk among the parties. In Section 4 we propose extended secure summation protocols for improved privacy against collusion.

2.4 Counting Bloom filters (CBFs)

In this section we propose a novel method of calculating the similarity of p𝑝p BFs using a CBF, which will provide increased privacy compared to using BFs for similarity calculation, as we will discuss in Section 6.2. A CBF c𝑐c of p𝑝p (p>1𝑝1p>1) BFs is an integer array data structure of the same length as the BFs (l𝑙l). It contains the counts of values in each bit position β,1≤β≤l𝛽1𝛽𝑙\beta,1\leq\beta\leq l over a set of p𝑝p BFs in its corresponding position, such that c​[β]=∑i=1pbi​[β]𝑐delimited-[]𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑏𝑖delimited-[]𝛽c[\beta]=\sum_{i=1}^{p}b_{i}[\beta], where c​[β]𝑐delimited-[]𝛽c[\beta] is the count value in the β𝛽\beta bit position of the CBF c𝑐c and bi​[β]∈[0,1]subscript𝑏𝑖delimited-[]𝛽01b_{i}[\beta]\in[0,1] provides the value in the bit position β𝛽\beta of BF bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i}. Given p𝑝p BFs (bit vectors) bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} with 1≤i≤p1𝑖𝑝1\leq i\leq p, the CBF c𝑐c can be generated by applying a vector addition operation between the bit vectors such that c=∑ibi𝑐subscript𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖c=\sum_{i}b_{i}.

Theorem 2.1

The Dice coefficient similarity of p𝑝p BFs can be calculated given only a CBF as:

D​i​c​e​_​s​i​m​(b1,⋯,bp)=p×|{β:c​[β]=p,1≤β≤l}|∑β=1lc​[β]𝐷𝑖𝑐𝑒_𝑠𝑖𝑚subscript𝑏1⋯subscript𝑏𝑝𝑝conditional-set𝛽formulae-sequence𝑐delimited-[]𝛽𝑝1𝛽𝑙superscriptsubscript𝛽1𝑙𝑐delimited-[]𝛽\displaystyle Dice\_sim(b_{1},\cdots,b_{p})=\frac{p\times|\{\beta:c[\beta]=p,1\leq\beta\leq l\}|}{\sum_{\beta=1}^{l}c[\beta]}
Proof 2.2.

The Dice coefficient similarity of p𝑝p BFs (b1subscript𝑏1b_{1},b2subscript𝑏2b_{2}, ⋯⋯\cdots, bpsubscript𝑏𝑝b_{p}) is determined by the sum of 111-bits (∑i=1pxisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑥𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{p}x_{i}) in the denominator of Eq. (1) and the number of common 111-bits (z𝑧z) in all p𝑝p BFs in the nominator of Eq. (1). The number of 111-bits in a BF bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} is xi=bi​[1]+bi​[2]+⋯+bi​[l]subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖delimited-[]1subscript𝑏𝑖delimited-[]2⋯subscript𝑏𝑖delimited-[]𝑙x_{i}=b_{i}[1]+b_{i}[2]+\cdots+b_{i}[l], with 1≤i≤p1𝑖𝑝1\leq i\leq p. The sum of 111-bits in all p𝑝p BFs is therefore ∑i=1pxi=∑i=1pbi​[1]+bi​[2]+⋯+bi​[l]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑏𝑖delimited-[]1subscript𝑏𝑖delimited-[]2⋯subscript𝑏𝑖delimited-[]𝑙\sum_{i=1}^{p}x_{i}=\sum_{i=1}^{p}b_{i}[1]+b_{i}[2]+\cdots+b_{i}[l]. The value in a bit position β𝛽\beta (1≤β≤l1𝛽𝑙1\leq\beta\leq l) of the CBF of these p𝑝p BFs is c​[β]=b1​[β]+b2​[β]+⋯+bp​[β]𝑐delimited-[]𝛽subscript𝑏1delimited-[]𝛽subscript𝑏2delimited-[]𝛽⋯subscript𝑏𝑝delimited-[]𝛽c[\beta]=b_{1}[\beta]+b_{2}[\beta]+\cdots+b_{p}[\beta]. The sum of values in all bit positions of the CBF is ∑β=1lc​[β]=∑β=1lb1​[β]+b2​[β]+⋯+bp​[β]superscriptsubscript𝛽1𝑙𝑐delimited-[]𝛽superscriptsubscript𝛽1𝑙subscript𝑏1delimited-[]𝛽subscript𝑏2delimited-[]𝛽⋯subscript𝑏𝑝delimited-[]𝛽\sum_{\beta=1}^{l}c[\beta]=\sum_{\beta=1}^{l}b_{1}[\beta]+b_{2}[\beta]+\cdots+b_{p}[\beta] which is equal to ∑i=1pxi=∑i=1pbi​[1]+bi​[2]+⋯+bi​[l]superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑏𝑖delimited-[]1subscript𝑏𝑖delimited-[]2⋯subscript𝑏𝑖delimited-[]𝑙\sum_{i=1}^{p}x_{i}=\sum_{i=1}^{p}b_{i}[1]+b_{i}[2]+\cdots+b_{i}[l]. Further, if a bit position β𝛽\beta (1≤β≤l1𝛽𝑙1\leq\beta\leq l) contains 111 in all p𝑝p BFs, i.e. ∀i=1pbi​[β]=1superscriptsubscriptfor-all𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑏𝑖delimited-[]𝛽1\forall_{i=1}^{p}b_{i}[\beta]=1, then c​[β]=∑i=1pbi​[β]=p𝑐delimited-[]𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑏𝑖delimited-[]𝛽𝑝c[\beta]=\sum_{i=1}^{p}b_{i}[\beta]=p. Therefore, the common 111-bits (z𝑧z) that occur in all p𝑝p BFs can be calculated by counting the number of positions β∈c𝛽𝑐\beta\in c where c​[β]=p𝑐delimited-[]𝛽𝑝c[\beta]=p, while the sum of number of 111-bits (∑i=1pxisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑥𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{p}x_{i}) is calculated by summing the values in bit positions β∈c𝛽𝑐\beta\in c, ∑β=1lc​[β]superscriptsubscript𝛽1𝑙𝑐delimited-[]𝛽\sum_{\beta=1}^{l}c[\beta].

If the L​U𝐿𝑈LU gets only the CBF c𝑐c that contains the summed values in the bit positions of p𝑝p BFs instead of the actual p𝑝p BFs, then the L​U𝐿𝑈LU can calculate the Dice coefficient of p𝑝p BFs using Eq. (2.1) without learning any information about the individual bit positions of each party. As an example, the Dice coefficient calculation of the two BFs from the two parties P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} in Figure 2(a) is extended by using a CBF and secure summation to calculate the similarity by the L​U𝐿𝑈LU, as shown in Figure 2(b). The information gained by the L​U𝐿𝑈LU (and/or database owners) from a single CBF is less than p𝑝p BFs (i.e. CBFs provide increased privacy compared to BFs), as theoretically proven in Section 6.2 and empirically validated in Section 7.

3 Multi-party PPRL algorithm

Our protocol allows efficient, approximate, and private linking of records based on their masked QID values in multiple databases from p𝑝p (≥2)absent2(\geq 2) sources/parties. We first describe a basic naïve protocol based on CBFs, which we name as ‘NAI’, and in Section 5 we then propose improved communication patterns for this protocol to make it more scalable. The steps of our protocol are listed below.

  • •

    Step 1:  The parties agree upon the following parameter values: the BF length l𝑙l; the k𝑘k hashing functions h1,…,hksubscriptℎ1…subscriptℎ𝑘h_{1},\ldots,h_{k} to be used; the length (in characters) of grams q𝑞q; a minimum similarity threshold value stsubscript𝑠𝑡s_{t} (0≤st≤10subscript𝑠𝑡10\leq s_{t}\leq 1), above which a set of records is classified as a match; a private blocking function b​l​o​c​k​(⋅)𝑏𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑘⋅block(\cdot); the blocking keys [2] B𝐵B used for blocking; and a set of QID attributes A𝐴A used for the linkage.

  • •

    Step 2:  Each party Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} (1≤i≤p1𝑖𝑝1\leq i\leq p) individually applies a private blocking function [43] b​l​o​c​k​(⋅)𝑏𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑘⋅block(\cdot) to reduce the number of candidate sets of records 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C} (from ∏ipnisuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖𝑝subscript𝑛𝑖\prod_{i}^{p}n_{i}, where ni=|𝐃i|subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝐃𝑖n_{i}=|\mathbf{D}_{i}| is the number of records in 𝐃isubscript𝐃𝑖\mathbf{D}_{i} held by party Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}), which otherwise becomes prohibitive even for moderate nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} and p𝑝p. The b​l​o​c​k​(⋅)𝑏𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑘⋅block(\cdot) function groups records according to their blocking key values (BKVs) [3] and only records with the same BKV (i.e. records in the same block) from different parties are then compared and classified using our protocol. A phonetic-based blocking [2] or any of the existing multi-party blocking techniques for PPRL [26, 27] can be used as the b​l​o​c​k​(⋅)𝑏𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑘⋅block(\cdot) function.

  • •

    Step 3:  Each party Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} hash-maps the q𝑞q-gram values of QIDs A𝐴A of each of its nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} records in their respective databases 𝐃isubscript𝐃𝑖\mathbf{D}_{i} into nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} BFs (one BF per record in 𝐃isubscript𝐃𝑖\mathbf{D}_{i}) of length l𝑙l using the hash functions h1,…,hksubscriptℎ1…subscriptℎ𝑘h_{1},\ldots,h_{k}. It is crucial to set the BF related parameters in an optimal way that balances all three properties of PPRL (complexity, quality, and privacy). We further discuss parameter setting for BFs used in our protocol in Section 6.

  • •

    Step 4:  In the next step, the parties initiate a secure summation protocol to securely perform vector addition between their BFs in order to generate a CBF for each set of candidate records 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C}. This secure summation can be initiated by an external linkage unit L​U𝐿𝑈LU that provides a vector (of length l𝑙l) of random values or by one of the parties (as will be discussed further in Section 5). This process is outlined in Algorithm 1.

    In lines 3-6, the L​U𝐿𝑈LU or the party that initiated the communication (we assume P1subscript𝑃1P_{1}) sends or uses, respectively, a random vector 𝐑′​[r​e​c]superscript𝐑′delimited-[]𝑟𝑒𝑐\mathbf{R^{\prime}}[rec] for each record r​e​c∈𝐃1M𝑟𝑒𝑐superscriptsubscript𝐃1𝑀rec\in\mathbf{D}_{1}^{M} to sum with the party’s BF vector bi∈𝐃iMsubscript𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐃𝑖𝑀b_{i}\in\mathbf{D}_{i}^{M} (i=1𝑖1i=1) by applying a vector addition operation. The summed vectors 𝐑′​[r​e​c]+bi∈𝐂superscript𝐑′delimited-[]𝑟𝑒𝑐subscript𝑏𝑖𝐂\mathbf{R^{\prime}}[rec]+b_{i}\in\mathbf{C} are then sent to party Pi+1subscript𝑃𝑖1P_{i+1} in line 7. Party Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}, 2≤i≤p2𝑖𝑝2\leq i\leq p receives the summed vectors from Pi−1subscript𝑃𝑖1P_{i-1} (line 9) and adds its BF vector bi∈𝐃iMsubscript𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐃𝑖𝑀b_{i}\in\mathbf{D}_{i}^{M} to each candidate set c​s∈𝐂𝑐𝑠𝐂cs\in\mathbf{C} and sends the summed vectors to the next party Pi+1subscript𝑃𝑖1P_{i+1}. This process is repeated until the last party (i.e. Ppsubscript𝑃𝑝P_{p}) adds its bpsubscript𝑏𝑝b_{p} vector to each received summed vector 𝐑′​[r​e​c]+∑i=1p−1bisuperscript𝐑′delimited-[]𝑟𝑒𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝1subscript𝑏𝑖\mathbf{R^{\prime}}[rec]+\sum_{i=1}^{p-1}b_{i} from party Pp−1subscript𝑃𝑝1P_{p-1} and sends the final summed vector back to the L​U𝐿𝑈LU or P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} for each candidate set c​s𝑐𝑠cs, as shown in lines 8-17 in Algorithm 1.

  • •

    Step 5:  Finally, either the L​U𝐿𝑈LU or the first party, P1subscript𝑃1P_{1}, that has provided the random vectors 𝐑′superscript𝐑′\mathbf{R^{\prime}}, subtracts 𝐑′​[r​e​c]superscript𝐑′delimited-[]𝑟𝑒𝑐\mathbf{R^{\prime}}[rec] from the final summed vector 𝐑′​[r​e​c]+∑i=1pbisuperscript𝐑′delimited-[]𝑟𝑒𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑏𝑖\mathbf{R^{\prime}}[rec]+\sum_{i=1}^{p}b_{i} as received from the last party Ppsubscript𝑃𝑝P_{p} for each candidate set c​s∈𝐂𝑐𝑠𝐂cs\in\mathbf{C}. This is achieved by subtraction of vectors (i.e. c=𝐑′​[r​e​c]+∑i=1pbi−𝐑′​[r​e​c]𝑐superscript𝐑′delimited-[]𝑟𝑒𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑏𝑖superscript𝐑′delimited-[]𝑟𝑒𝑐c=\mathbf{R^{\prime}}[rec]+\sum_{i=1}^{p}b_{i}-\mathbf{R^{\prime}}[rec]), which is a special case of vector addition, as outlined in lines 2-4 in Algorithm 2. As shown in lines 5-7, the L​U𝐿𝑈LU or P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} then calculates the Dice coefficient similarity of each resulting CBF c𝑐c following Eq. (2.1) to classify the compared sets of records (BFs) within a block into matches and non-matches based on the similarity threshold stsubscript𝑠𝑡s_{t}. The final similarities of matching sets of records will be sent to all parties Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}, with 1≤i≤p1𝑖𝑝1\leq i\leq p, in lines 8-9 in Algorithm 2.

The basic secure summation protocol (BSS) used in this ’NAI’ protocol is vulnerable to collusion risk among the parties. Further, the number of candidate sets to be compared for multi-party linkage in this naïve method (NAI) is exponential in the number of parties and their dataset sizes, which is prohibitively large to be practically feasible (even with the existing private blocking and filtering approaches employed) [39]. Efficient communication patterns among the parties therefore need to be employed in order to make multi-party PPRL scalable and viable in real applications that require data of very large sizes from many parties to be integrated. In the following sections we propose extended secure summation protocols and two efficient communication patterns that not only improve the scalability of our multi-party PPRL protocol but also make it more secure (with less possible collusion among the parties).

4 Extended secure summation

The basic secure summation protocol (BSS) described in Section 2.3 is susceptible to collusion risk by the parties involved, where if two or more parties collude they are able to infer the input of another party. In order to overcome this risk (to improve privacy), we propose two extended secure summation protocols.

  • •

    Homomorphic-based secure summation (HSS): The partially homomorphic Paillier cryptosystem [24] is a reliable secure multi-party computation (SMC) technique for performing secure joint computation among several parties. In the HSS approach a pair of private and public keys is used for encrypting and decrypting the individual BF values. Successive encryption of the same value using the same public key generates different encrypted values with high probability, and decrypting the encrypted values using a private key returns the correct original value. The public key is known to all parties while the private key is known only to the L​U𝐿𝑈LU. Each party Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} receives summed vectors containing encrypted values to which Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} adds its encrypted 𝐛isubscript𝐛𝑖\mathbf{b}_{i} vector (using the public key) and sends the encrypted summed vectors to the next party. Without knowing the private key a party Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} cannot decrypt the received vectors and therefore colluding with a party to learn another party’s 𝐛jsubscript𝐛𝑗\mathbf{b}_{j} (with i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j) would be impossible.

  • •

    Salting-based (using random seed integers) secure summation (SSS): The HSS approach provides a secure solution compared to the BSS approach against collusion attacks at the cost of an excessive computation overhead, making it not scalable to linking multiple large databases. Therefore, we propose the SSS approach to provide security against collusion attacks in an efficient way. Salting has been used to defend against dictionary attacks on one-way hash functions where an additional string is concatenated with a value to be encrypted [32]. We adopt a similar concept in the SSS approach where the salting key is an additional random integer used by each party Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} individually when performing the secure summation. The salting key generated and used by each party is sent only to the L​U𝐿𝑈LU and therefore a party Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}’s BF values cannot be identified by means of collusion among the parties, as without knowing the salting key of Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} its BF values cannot be learned. Since the salting keys are random integer values, performing secure summation of BFs with the salting keys does not add any additional computation and communication overhead, except the communication of salting keys from parties to the L​U𝐿𝑈LU.

5 Communication patterns

In this section, we propose two variations of improved communication patterns for our protocol based on CBFs for multi-party scenarios with and without a linkage unit (L​U𝐿𝑈LU). The main idea of these improved communication patterns is to exploit the facts that most candidate sets are true non-matches (due to the class imbalance problem of record linkage [3]), and that a true matching set must have a high similarity between any sub-set of records in that set. Hence for multi-party PPRL applications with many parties it is promising to determine partial matches for a sub-set of parties and consider additional parties only for these partial matches.

The parties are first arranged into rings of size r𝑟r (with r≤p𝑟𝑝r\leq p) based on the value for the parameter rmsubscript𝑟𝑚r_{m}, the minimum number of parties per ring (r≥rm𝑟subscript𝑟𝑚r\geq r_{m}). The value of rmsubscript𝑟𝑚r_{m} needs to be carefully chosen, as it has a trade-off between scalability (complexity) and privacy. The higher the value for rmsubscript𝑟𝑚r_{m} is, the better the privacy of the protocol because the resulting CBFs are more difficult to exploit with an inference attack (by mapping the CBFs to known values in a global database to infer their underlying unencoded values), as will be discussed in Section 6.2. On the other hand, higher values of rmsubscript𝑟𝑚r_{m} results in lower scalability to large datasets across many parties because the number of comparisons required per ring exponentially increases with the ring size r𝑟r.

5.1 Sequential communication

In this first proposed communication pattern (SEQ), which requires a L​U𝐿𝑈LU, the matches found in one ring are compared with the candidate sets in the next ring resulting in a set of matches from both rings which will then be compared with the candidate sets in the following ring, and so on. This communication is carried out sequentially until the matches from all rings are found by the L​U𝐿𝑈LU. Figure 3 illustrates the SEQ approach for four rings with r=2𝑟2r=2 parties in each ring.

Algorithm 3 details the steps of the SEQ communication pattern. First the parties are grouped in rings using the function g​r​o​u​p​(⋅)𝑔𝑟𝑜𝑢𝑝⋅group(\cdot) (line 2 in Algorithm 3). Different number of parties (≥rmabsentsubscript𝑟𝑚\geq r_{m}) can be grouped into different rings. The value for rmsubscript𝑟𝑚r_{m} can be agreed upon by the parties to any value rm≥2subscript𝑟𝑚2r_{m}\geq 2 at the trade-off between privacy and scalability, as will be discussed in Section 6.

To minimize the number of comparisons that are required, the grouping of parties into rings is ideally done in an ascending order of the size of their datasets. In this way, the first ring will generate a smaller number of matches, which then have to be compared with the candidate sets in the following rings. This reduces the computational complexity compared to initially larger number of matches being generated by the first ring if the parties in the first ring are the ones with the largest databases.

A loop is iterated over rings in line 3 of Algorithm 3 and then the parties in rings are iterated in line 4. Each party in r​i​n​g𝑟𝑖𝑛𝑔ring retrieves its records in line 5 and a loop is iterated over these records in line 7 to append each of them to every candidate record set (from previous party, except for the first party that appends to empty sets) stored in 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C} (line 8). Next, a secure summation protocol is applied in line 9 using s​e​c​_​s​u​m​(⋅)𝑠𝑒𝑐_𝑠𝑢𝑚⋅sec\_sum(\cdot) function on the candidate sets of BFs 𝐂𝐂\mathbf{C} identified in r​i​n​g𝑟𝑖𝑛𝑔ring in order to generate CBFs for each candidate set. In lines 10-12, each CBF c𝑐c generated is then used to calculate the Dice similarity (D​i​c​e​_​s​i​m𝐷𝑖𝑐𝑒_𝑠𝑖𝑚Dice\_sim) of the candidate set (c​s𝑐𝑠cs) and if the D​i​c​e​_​s​i​m​(c​s)≥st𝐷𝑖𝑐𝑒_𝑠𝑖𝑚𝑐𝑠subscript𝑠𝑡Dice\_sim(cs)\geq s_{t} (line 13) then c​s𝑐𝑠cs is added into the list of matches 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{M} identified in the ring (line 14), which will then be used as an input (line 15) in the next ring.

The risk of collusion between parties in order to identify data about another party can be reduced in this approach by using different BF encodings in different iterations. For example, if the encoding used in ring 1 in Figure 3 is unknown to parties in ring 2, then the collusion between the L​U𝐿𝑈LU and parties in ring 2 would not reveal sufficient information to infer the actual values masked in the BFs in ring 1. Hence, parties might wish to be grouped with certain other parties in the same ring for better privacy protection.

5.2 Ring by ring communication

In the absence of a trusted L​U𝐿𝑈LU, as is required by the previously described SEQ communication approach, we propose a ring by ring communication pattern (RBR) for comparing CBFs from multiple parties without using a L​U𝐿𝑈LU. This method is illustrated in Figure 4 for three rings with r=3𝑟3r=3 parties in each ring, while Algorithm 4 outlines the steps of RBR in detail. Similar to SEQ, parties are grouped into rings using the g​r​o​u​p​(⋅)𝑔𝑟𝑜𝑢𝑝⋅group(\cdot) function (line 1 in Algorithm 4). The value for rmsubscript𝑟𝑚r_{m} in RBR should be set to rm≥3subscript𝑟𝑚3r_{m}\geq 3, as a minimum of three parties are required in each ring to perform secure summation without a L​U𝐿𝑈LU.

The RBR method consists of two phases. In the first phase (lines 2-14 in Algorithm 4), the parties in each ring (lines 2-4) individually perform secure summation among them using s​e​c​_​s​u​m​(⋅)𝑠𝑒𝑐_𝑠𝑢𝑚⋅sec\_sum(\cdot) (line 9) on their sets of candidate records 𝐂r​i​n​gsubscript𝐂𝑟𝑖𝑛𝑔\mathbf{C}_{ring} (generated in lines 5-8) to generate the CBFs 𝐂′r​i​n​gsubscriptsuperscript𝐂′𝑟𝑖𝑛𝑔\mathbf{C^{\prime}}_{ring}, and calculate their similarities to identify matches 𝐌r​i​n​gsubscript𝐌𝑟𝑖𝑛𝑔\mathbf{M}_{ring} in each ring (as shown in lines 10-14). In the second phase in lines 16-26, all parties then perform secure summation among them on the matches identified in each ring 𝐌r​i​n​gsubscript𝐌𝑟𝑖𝑛𝑔\mathbf{M}_{ring} in order to identify matches 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{M} from all p𝑝p parties.

Every ring in the first phase can employ a different set of BF parameters to reduce the possibility of collusion between a set of parties in different rings. In the second phase, all parties then have to agree on another set of parameters for BF encodings of the matches identified in rings in the first phase. In addition, the rings in the first phase can be processed independently and in parallel in a distributed environment making the RBR more scalable (than the SEQ) with larger dataset sizes.

6 Analysis of the protocol

In this section we analyze our multi-party PPRL protocol in terms of complexity, privacy, and linkage quality.

6.1 Complexity analysis

We assume p𝑝p parties participate in the protocol, each having a database of n𝑛n records. We assume a private blocking/indexing technique employed in the blocking step forms b≤n𝑏𝑛b\leq n blocks for each party. In Step 1 of our protocol, the agreement of parameters has a constant communication complexity. Blocking the databases in Step 2 has O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) computation complexity at each party, and finding the intersection of blocks from all parties has a communication complexity of O​(p⋅b)𝑂⋅𝑝𝑏O(p\cdot b) and a computation complexity of O​(b⋅l​o​g​b)𝑂⋅𝑏𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑏O(b\cdot log~{}b) at each party, as p⋅b⋅𝑝𝑏p\cdot b BKVs need to be securely communicated, and for each of the b𝑏b BKVs a search operation of O​(l​o​g​b)𝑂𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑏O(log~{}b) is required in order to identify the intersection set. Assuming the average number of q𝑞q-grams in the QID attributes A𝐴A of each record is g𝑔g, the masking of QID values of records into BFs of length l𝑙l using k𝑘k hash functions for n𝑛n records in Step 3 is O​(n⋅g⋅k)𝑂⋅𝑛𝑔𝑘O(n\cdot g\cdot k) at each party.

Steps 4 and 5 consist of the secure summation of BF vectors to calculate the CBFs of candidate sets. Our extended secure summation protocols HSS and SSS aim to improve privacy at the cost of complexity overhead. The extended HSS protocol requires n⋅l⋅p⋅𝑛𝑙𝑝n\cdot l\cdot p encrypted values (long integers of 4 bytes each) to be exchanged among the parties, while the basic secure summation (BSS) and SSS require exchanging n⋅l⋅p⋅𝑛𝑙𝑝n\cdot l\cdot p short integer values (of 2 bytes each), which is more efficient compared to HSS. Further, the homomorphic encryption and decryption functions used in HSS are computationally expensive compared to simple vector addition and subtraction operations [19].

With the simplified assumption that all blocks are of equal size n/b𝑛𝑏n/b, i.e. contain n/b𝑛𝑏n/b BFs at each party, then using the NAI communication method in each block (n/b)psuperscript𝑛𝑏𝑝(n/b)^{p} candidate sets of BFs (i.e. all candidate sets of records in a block) have to be generated and their CBFs calculated. The first party performs b​(n/b)𝑏𝑛𝑏b(n/b) summations, the second party b​(n/b)2𝑏superscript𝑛𝑏2b(n/b)^{2}, and finally b​(n/b)p𝑏superscript𝑛𝑏𝑝b(n/b)^{p} summations are performed by the last party, leading to a total of O​(∑i=1pb​(n/b)i)𝑂superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝𝑏superscript𝑛𝑏𝑖O(\sum_{i=1}^{p}b(n/b)^{i}) summations in Step 4.

In Step 5, either the linkage unit L​U𝐿𝑈LU or the first party that initiated the secure summation protocol performs a vector subtraction operation (subtracts the random vectors from the summed vectors) on all the candidate sets, resulting in b​(n/b)p𝑏superscript𝑛𝑏𝑝b(n/b)^{p} CBFs. The similarities of these CBFs are then calculated and matches classified, which requires O​(b​(n/b)p)𝑂𝑏superscript𝑛𝑏𝑝O(b(n/b)^{p}) computations. This combinatorial complexity currently limits the NAI linkage to a small number of parties or a large number of small blocks (i.e. p𝑝p or n/b𝑛𝑏n/b has to be small).

The communication patterns SEQ and RBR proposed in Sections 5.1 and 5.2, respectively, improve Steps 4 and 5 significantly (depending on the number of parties per ring, r𝑟r) by reducing the computation and communication complexities. In general the complexities are reduced from the exponential growth with p𝑝p down to r+1𝑟1r+1 in SEQ and m​a​x​(r,p/r)𝑚𝑎𝑥𝑟𝑝𝑟max(r,p/r) in RBR. With the simplified assumption that each ring has r𝑟r parties, the computation and communication complexities of the SEQ and RBR methods are as follows.

In the SEQ method, b​(n/b)r𝑏superscript𝑛𝑏𝑟b(n/b)^{r} candidate sets are processed in the first ring and b​(n/b)r+1𝑏superscript𝑛𝑏𝑟1b(n/b)^{r+1} in each of the remaining rings (i.e. b​(n/b)𝑏𝑛𝑏b(n/b) matching sets, in the worst case, from the previous ring are compared with the b​(n/b)r𝑏superscript𝑛𝑏𝑟b(n/b)^{r} sets in each ring), resulting in total computation and communication complexities of O(∑i=1rb(n/b)iO(\sum_{i=1}^{r}b(n/b)^{i} + (∑i=1r+1b​(n/b)i⋅(p/r−1))superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑟1⋅𝑏superscript𝑛𝑏𝑖𝑝𝑟1(\sum_{i=1}^{r+1}b(n/b)^{i}\cdot(p/r-1)) (with r<p𝑟𝑝r<p). The computation and communication complexities of the RBR method is O(∑i=1rb(n/b)i⋅(p/r)O(\sum_{i=1}^{r}b(n/b)^{i}\cdot(p/r) + ∑i=1p/rb(n/b)i)\sum_{i=1}^{p/r}b(n/b)^{i}), where the first phase requires b​(n/b)r𝑏superscript𝑛𝑏𝑟b(n/b)^{r} total candidate sets to be processed in each of the p/r𝑝𝑟p/r rings and the second phase compares the b​(n/b)𝑏𝑛𝑏b(n/b) matching sets from each ring.

Overall, the complexity of the NAI method is O​(b​(n/b)p)𝑂𝑏superscript𝑛𝑏𝑝O(b(n/b)^{p}), the SEQ method is O​(b​(n/b)r+1⋅p/r)𝑂⋅𝑏superscript𝑛𝑏𝑟1𝑝𝑟O(b(n/b)^{r+1}\cdot p/r), and the RBR method is O(max(b(n/b)r⋅p/r,b(n/b)p/r)O(max(b(n/b)^{r}\cdot p/r,b(n/b)^{p/r}). This theoretical analysis shows that the two proposed communication methods SEQ and RBR are computationally efficient compared to the NAI method. Depending on the values for p𝑝p and r𝑟r, the SEQ and RBR methods outperform each other.

The memory size required for a CBF is 2xsuperscript2𝑥2^{x}, which is 2x≥psuperscript2𝑥𝑝2^{x}\geq p, bits for every position in the CBF. If the length of CBF is l𝑙l, the total memory consumption is l×⌈l​o​g2​(p)⌉𝑙𝑙𝑜subscript𝑔2𝑝l\times\lceil log_{2}(p)\rceil. For p𝑝p BFs the memory required is 111 bit for every position in the BF, and therefore the total memory consumption of 1×l×p1𝑙𝑝1\times l\times p. CBF requires relatively more memory than using BFs when p𝑝p is small, however with increasing number of p𝑝p in multi-party PPRL, a CBF requires significantly lower memory compared to BFs. For example, when p=5𝑝5p=5 and l=1,000𝑙1000l=1,000 the respective memory sizes of a CBF and corresponding BFs are 1000×⌈l​o​g2​(5)⌉=30001000𝑙𝑜subscript𝑔2530001000\times\lceil log_{2}(5)\rceil=3000 bits and 1×1000×5=500011000550001\times 1000\times 5=5000 bits, while for p=10𝑝10p=10 and l=1,000𝑙1000l=1,000 they are 1000×⌈l​o​g2​(10)⌉=40001000𝑙𝑜subscript𝑔21040001000\times\lceil log_{2}(10)\rceil=4000 bits and 1×1000×10=100001100010100001\times 1000\times 10=10000 bits, respectively.

6.2 Privacy analysis

As with most of the existing PPRL approaches, we assume that all parties follow the honest-but-curious (semi-honest) adversary model [43], where the parties follow the protocol while being curious to learn the other parties’ data by means of inference attacks on input data [41] or collusion [43]. To analyze the privacy against inference attacks, we discuss what the parties can learn through inference attacks or collusion during the protocol. We assume a trusted L​U𝐿𝑈LU is available, which does not collude with any parties, as is commonly used in many practical PPRL applications [29].

However, collusion among the database owners is a privacy risk in the basic secure summation protocol where a set of parties can collude to learn the BF of another party using their received summation values. To overcome this problem, in Section 4 we have proposed two extended secure summation protocols, HSS and SSS. The HSS protocol uses homomorphic encryptions for secure summation which makes the protocol more secure because without knowing the private key (which is only known to the L​U𝐿𝑈LU) identifying a party’s BF values by means of collusion will not be successful. However, this protocol encrypts each integer value in a BF (in total l𝑙l values for each BF) into a hash key (long integers) and thus incurs a very large communication overhead making the protocol not viable for linkage of multiple large databases. The SSS protocol similarly makes the protocol more secure by adding additional integer values as salting keys by each party individually (known only to the L​U𝐿𝑈LU) in the secure summation, such that without knowing the salting key value collusion among parties to learn a party’s BF is not possible. Compared to HSS, the SSS approach does not incur any expensive communication overhead as the salting keys are small integer values.

Communication occurs among the parties in Step 1 of our protocol (as described in Section 3) where they agree on parameter settings, and in Steps 4 and 5 where they participate in a secure summation protocol. The agreement of parameter settings in Step 1 does not reveal any sensitive information about the underlying data. Secure summation involves partial (masked) data exchange where the parties communicate the partial and full summations of their BFs (1) among them in Step 4 and (2) to the L​U𝐿𝑈LU or the first party that initiated the communication in Step 5, respectively, to calculate the CBFs of the candidate sets and their similarities.

The L​U𝐿𝑈LU (in SEQ or NAI) or the first party in each ring (in RBR) receives the CBFs of candidate sets in each ring. Compared to calculating similarities of sets using their BFs directly, using a CBF makes the inference attack on individual BFs and thus their q𝑞q-grams (strings) mapped into them more difficult. An inference attack allows an adversary to map a list of known values from a global dataset (e.g. q𝑞q-grams or attribute values from a public telephone directory) to the encoded values (BFs or CBF) using background information (such as frequency) [41, 16]. The only information that can be learned from such an inference attack using a CBF c𝑐c of a set of x𝑥x BFs (summed over x𝑥x parties, where either x=p𝑥𝑝x=p in NAI and RBR methods or x=r𝑥𝑟x=r in SEQ and RBR methods) is if a bit position in c𝑐c is either 00 or x𝑥x which means it is set to 00 or 111, respectively, in the BFs from all x𝑥x parties.

Proposition 1.

The probability of identifying the original (unencoded) values of x𝑥x (x>1𝑥1x>1) individual records Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} (with 1≤i≤x1𝑖𝑥1\leq i\leq x) given a single CBF c𝑐c is smaller than the probability of identifying the original (unencoded values) of Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} given x𝑥x individual BFs bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i}, 1≤i≤x1𝑖𝑥1\leq i\leq x.

∀i=1xP​r​(Ri|c)<P​r​(Ri|bi)superscriptsubscriptfor-all𝑖1𝑥𝑃𝑟conditionalsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑐𝑃𝑟conditionalsubscript𝑅𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖\displaystyle\forall_{i=1}^{x}Pr(R_{i}|c)<Pr(R_{i}|b_{i})
Proof 6.1.

Assume the number of original (unencoded) values that can be mapped to a masked BF pattern bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} from an inference attack is ngsubscript𝑛𝑔n_{g}. ng=1subscript𝑛𝑔1n_{g}=1 in the worst case, where a one-to-one mapping exists between the masked BF bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} and the original unencoded value of Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i}. The probability of identifying the original value given a BF in the worst case scenario is therefore P​r​(Ri|bi)=1/ng=1.0𝑃𝑟conditionalsubscript𝑅𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑔1.0Pr(R_{i}|b_{i})=1/n_{g}=1.0. However, a CBF represents x𝑥x BFs and thus at least (in the worst case) x𝑥x original (unencoded) values, which leads to a maximum of P​r​(Ri|c)=1/x𝑃𝑟conditionalsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑐1𝑥Pr(R_{i}|c)=1/x with x>1𝑥1x>1 (when x=1𝑥1x=1, c≡b1𝑐subscript𝑏1c\equiv b_{1}). Hence, ∀i=1xP​r​(Ri|c)<P​r​(Ri|bi)superscriptsubscriptfor-all𝑖1𝑥𝑃𝑟conditionalsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑐𝑃𝑟conditionalsubscript𝑅𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖\forall_{i=1}^{x}Pr(R_{i}|c)<Pr(R_{i}|b_{i}).

We will empirically evaluate and compare the amount of privacy provided by masking records into CBFs and BFs against an inference attack in Section 7.5. A larger number of parties in a ring r𝑟r (i.e. the larger the value for x𝑥x) results in an increase in the difficulty of an inference attack (a smaller probability of suspicion 1/x1𝑥1/x) by the adversary (L​U𝐿𝑈LU or the first party in each ring for SEQ and RBR, respectively) at the cost of more candidate set comparisons.

Further, using different hash encodings h1,⋯,hksubscriptℎ1⋯subscriptℎ𝑘h_{1},\cdots,h_{k} by different rings in our SEQ and RBR methods improves privacy compared to the NAI method by reducing the possibilities of collusions, as discussed in Section 5. Since the hash functions used by parties in ring 1, for example, are not known to parties in other rings, a collusion between parties in other rings and / or the L​U𝐿𝑈LU will not be successful in inferring the original values of parties in ring 1. A careful grouping of parties is therefore required to improve privacy in a multi-party setting (for example, L​U𝐿𝑈LU randomly groups or changes the grouping for different blocks). More specifically, when p𝑝p parties are involved in the linkage, the maximum number of possible combinations for collusion in NAI method is ∑i=1p(p−1)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝𝑝1\sum_{i=1}^{p}(p-1), while in SEQ and RBR it is ∑i=1p/r∑j=1r(r−1)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑟𝑟1\sum_{i=1}^{p/r}\sum_{j=1}^{r}(r-1). For example, with p=9𝑝9p=9 parties the NAI method has 727272 possibilities to collude while grouping into equal sized rings (r=3𝑟3r=3) leads to only 181818 different collusion possibilities.

The values for the number of hash functions used (k𝑘k) and the length of the BF (l𝑙l) provide a trade-off between the linkage quality and privacy [34]. The higher the value for k/l𝑘𝑙k/l, the higher the privacy and the lower the quality of linkage, because the number of q𝑞q-grams mapped to a single bit (and therefore the number of resulting collisions) increases, which leads to lower linkage quality but makes it more difficult for an adversary to learn the possible q𝑞q-gram combinations [16]. The CLK encoding method (as discussed in Section 2.1) of hash-mapping several QID values from each record into one compound BF [34, 38] makes it even more difficult for an adversary to learn individual QID values that correspond to a revealed bit pattern in a BF.

6.3 Linkage quality analysis

Our protocol supports approximate matching of QID values, in that data errors and variations are taken into account depending on the minimum similarity threshold stsubscript𝑠𝑡s_{t} used. The quality of BF-based masking depends on the BF parameterization [34, 37]. For a given BF length, l𝑙l, and the number of elements g𝑔g (e.g. q𝑞q-grams) to be inserted into the BF, the optimal number of hash functions, k𝑘k, that minimizes the false positive rate f𝑓f (of a collision of two different q𝑞q-grams being mapped to the same bit position), is calculated as [21] k=l/g​l​n​(2)𝑘𝑙𝑔𝑙𝑛2k=l/g~{}ln(2), leading to a false positive rate of f=(1/2l​n​(2))l/g𝑓superscript1superscript2𝑙𝑛2𝑙𝑔f=(1/2^{ln(2)})^{l/g}.

While k𝑘k and l𝑙l determine the computational aspects of BF masking, linkage quality and privacy will be determined by the false positive rate f𝑓f. A higher value for f𝑓f will mean a larger number of false matches and thus lower linkage quality [21, 34]. In our experimental evaluation we will set the BF parameters for our approach according to the discussion presented here and following earlier BF work in PPRL [9, 34, 38, 37].

7 Experimental evaluation

In this section, we empirically evaluate the performance of our protocol (which we refer as AM-CBF for Approximate Matching with Counting BFs) with the SEQ, RBR, and NAI communication patterns in terms of the three properties of PPRL, scalability (complexity), linkage quality, and privacy. We describe the competing baseline methods in Section 7.1, the datasets used in Section 7.2, the evaluation measures in Section 7.3, and the experimental settings in Section 7.4. We then discuss the experimental results in Section 7.5.

7.1 Baseline methods

We use Lai et al. [17]’s exact matching BF-based PPRL approach (referred as EM-BF for Exact Matching with BFs) and Vatsalan and Christen [39, 40]’s approximate matching BF-based PPRL approach (AM-BF for Approximate Matching with BFs) as competing baseline methods to compare with our proposed approach. Since other existing approaches for multi-party PPRL (as reviewed in Section 8) are either based on expensive cryptographic techniques or applicable to categorical data only, we do not compare them with our approach.

Lai et al.’s EM-BF approach [17] performs exact matching of QIDs across multiple parties using BFs. In their approach, the QID values of all records in a dataset are first converted into one BF. Each party then partitions its BF into segments according to the number of parties involved in the linkage, and sends these segments to the corresponding other parties. The segments received by a party are combined using a conjunction (logical AND) operation. The resulting conjuncted BF segments are then exchanged between the parties to construct the full conjuncted BF. Each party checks its own full BF of each record with the conjuncted BF, and if the membership test is successful then the record is considered to be a match. Though the cost of this approach is low since the computation is completely distributed between the parties and the processing of BFs is fast, the approach can only perform exact matching.

Vatsalan and Christen proposed AM-BF [39, 40] by adapting the idea used in EM-BF of distributively computing the conjunction of a set of BFs from multiple parties to perform privacy-preserving approximate matching for multi-party PPRL. Once the conjuncted BF segments are computed by the respective parties, a secure summation protocol is initiated among the parties to securely sum the number of common 111-bits in the conjuncted BF segments as well as the total number of 111-bits in each party’s BF. These two sums are then used to calculate the Dice coefficient similarity of the set of BFs. A filtering approach is employed to reduce the number of comparisons based on segment similarity, such that if a sub-set of BF segments of a candidate set (as calculated by a respective party) has lower similarity then the BFs do not have to be compared with any of the BFs from the other parties.

Both EM-BF and AM-BF approaches use the NAI method for comparing and classifying candidate sets of records.

7.2 Datasets

To provide a realistic evaluation of our approach, we based all our experiments on a large real-world database, the North Carolina Voter Registration (NCVR) database as available from ftp://alt.ncsbe.gov/data/. This database has been used for the evaluation of various other PPRL approaches [9, 26, 27, 39, 40, 41]. We have downloaded this database every second month since October 2011 and built a combined temporal dataset that contains over 8 million records of voters’ names and addresses [4]. We are not aware of any available real-world dataset that contains records from more than two parties that would allow us to evaluate multi-party PPRL approaches. We therefore generated, based on the real NCVR database, a series of sub-sets for multiple parties, as will be described next.

To allow the evaluation of our approach with different number of parties, with different dataset sizes, and with data of different quality, we used and modified a recently proposed data corruptor [5, 36] to generate various datasets with different characteristics based on randomly selected records from the NCVR database. The identifiers of the selected and modified records were kept the same, which allows us to identify true and false matches and therefore evaluate linkage quality, as described below. Specifically, we extracted sub-sets of 5,00050005,000, 10,0001000010,000, 50,0005000050,000, 100,000100000100,000, 500,000500000500,000, and 1,000,00010000001,000,000 records from the NCVR to generate datasets for 333, 555, 777, and 101010 parties, where the number of matching records is set to 50% (i.e. half of selected records occur in the datasets of all parties).

To evaluate how the approaches work with ‘dirty’ data, we created several series of datasets for each of the datasets generated above, where we included a varying number of corrupted records into the sets of overlapping records (0%percent00\%, 20%percent2020\%, and 40%percent4040\%). We applied various corruption functions on randomly selected attribute values, including character edit operations (insertions, deletions, substitutions, and transpositions), and optical character recognition and phonetic modifications based on look-up tables and corruption rules [5]. This means that a certain percentage of records in the overlap were modified for randomly selected parties, while the original values were kept for the other parties. Therefore, some of these records are exact duplicates across some parties in a set, but are only approximately matching duplicates across the other parties in the set. This simulates, for example, the situation where three out of five hospitals have the correct and complete contact details (like name and address) of a certain patient, while in the fourth and fifth hospitals some of the details of the same patient are different.

7.3 Evaluation measures

We evaluate the three properties of PPRL using the following evaluation measures. The complexity (scalability) of linkage is measured by runtime, communication size, and the number of comparisons required for the linkage. The quality of the achieved linkage is measured using the F-measure, calculated on classified matches and non-matches, that has widely been used in record linkage, information retrieval and data mining [2].

In line with other work in PPRL [26, 39, 40, 41], we evaluate privacy using disclosure risk (DR) measures based on the probability of suspicion, i.e. the likelihood a masked (encoded) database record in 𝐃Msuperscript𝐃𝑀\mathbf{D}^{M} can be matched with one or several (masked) record(s) in a publicly available global database 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G}. The probability of suspicion for a masked value/record RMsuperscript𝑅𝑀R^{M}, P​r​(RM)𝑃𝑟superscript𝑅𝑀Pr(R^{M}), is calculated as 1/ng1subscript𝑛𝑔1/n_{g} where ngsubscript𝑛𝑔n_{g} is the number of possible matches in 𝐆Msuperscript𝐆𝑀\mathbf{G}^{M} to the masked value RMsuperscript𝑅𝑀R^{M}. We conducted a frequency linkage attack [41] by mapping the exchanged bit information in the BFs generated from 𝐃Msuperscript𝐃𝑀\mathbf{D}^{M} to the BFs generated from 𝐆Msuperscript𝐆𝑀\mathbf{G}^{M}. We used the worst case scenario where 𝐆≡𝐃𝐆𝐃\mathbf{G}\equiv\mathbf{D}, because when 𝐆≡𝐃𝐆𝐃\mathbf{G}\equiv\mathbf{D} there will be a one-to-one exact matching of a global value for each value in 𝐃𝐃\mathbf{D}. Based on such linkage attack, we calculate the following disclosure risk measures, as proposed by Vatsalan et al. [41].

  • •

    Mean disclosure risk (D​RM​e​a​n𝐷subscript𝑅𝑀𝑒𝑎𝑛DR_{Mean}): This calculates the average risk (∑i|𝐃M|superscriptsubscript𝑖superscript𝐃𝑀\sum_{i}^{|\mathbf{D}^{M}|} P​r​(RiM)/|𝐃M|𝑃𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑀superscript𝐃𝑀Pr(R_{i}^{M})/|\mathbf{D}^{M}|) of any sensitive value in 𝐃Msuperscript𝐃𝑀\mathbf{D}^{M} being re-identified.

  • •

    Marketer disclosure risk (D​RM​a​r​k𝐷subscript𝑅𝑀𝑎𝑟𝑘DR_{Mark}): This is calculated as the proportion of masked records in 𝐃Msuperscript𝐃𝑀\mathbf{D}^{M} that match to exactly one masked record in 𝐆Msuperscript𝐆𝑀\mathbf{G}^{M} (|{RM∈𝐃M:P​r​(RM)=1.0}|/|𝐃M|conditional-setsuperscript𝑅𝑀superscript𝐃𝑀𝑃𝑟superscript𝑅𝑀1.0superscript𝐃𝑀|\{R^{M}\in\mathbf{D}^{M}:Pr(R^{M})=1.0\}|/|\mathbf{D}^{M}|).

7.4 Experimental settings

We implemented both our proposed approach and the competing baseline approaches in Python 2.7.3, and ran all experiments on a server with four 6-core 64-bit Intel Xeon 2.4 GHz CPUs, 128 GBytes of memory and running Ubuntu 14.04. The programs and test datasets are available from the authors.

Following the discussion in Section 6.3 and other work in PPRL [9, 33, 38], we set the parameters as BF length l=500𝑙500l=500, the number of hash functions k=20𝑘20k=20, the length of grams q=2𝑞2q=2, the minimum similarity threshold st=0.8subscript𝑠𝑡0.8s_{t}=0.8, and the number of parties p=[3,5,7,10]𝑝35710p=[3,5,7,10]. For the SEQ method the minimum number of parties per ring was set to rm=2subscript𝑟𝑚2r_{m}=2 and for the RBR method rm=3subscript𝑟𝑚3r_{m}=3. The attributes first name, last name, city, and zipcode were used as the QIDs in the linkage. We applied a Soundex-based phonetic blocking [2] for the private blocking step in all approaches, which results in a set of blocks on which we individually conduct private comparison and classification.

The experiments are two-fold. In the first part we evaluate the scalability of our approach with proposed communication patterns and compare with the NAI method. In the second part we compare the complexity, linkage quality, and privacy of our approach (with the SEQ approach as it gave the best results in the first part) with baseline methods. We used the first name and last name attributes as the blocking keys in the second set of experiments and all four attributes in the first set of scalability experiments in order to allow for comparative evaluation with the NAI method (as we were unable to run experiments for the NAI method on larger datasets with larger p𝑝p when only two blocking attributes were used).

7.5 Discussion

Table 1 shows the runtime and memory size required and the F-measure results achieved with the three secure summation protocols. As can be seen, the HSS requires significantly higher runtime and memory (which is not practical in real applications) to improve privacy against collusion attacks on the BSS without compromising the F-measure results. However, the SSS approach requires similar runtime and memory as the BSS for improving privacy against collusions with no loss in linkage quality. We therefore use SSS in all following experiments.

Figures 5 (a) and (b) show the complexity of our AM-CBF approach with the proposed communication patterns SEQ and RBR in terms of runtime and communication size (comm), while Figure 5 (c) shows the runtime and communication size required by the NAI communication pattern. As the figures show the proposed communication methods improve the scalability of our multi-party approach by significantly reducing the number of candidate sets (and thereby the complexities) compared to the NAI method (which has been used in many existing solutions including the baseline approaches). As discussed in Section 6.1, SEQ is faster than RBR (Figure 5 (a)). When p=5𝑝5p=5, RBR is equivalent to NAI (as we set rm=3subscript𝑟𝑚3r_{m}=3). Both SEQ and RBR are scalable (almost linear) with the dataset size and the number of parties compared to the NAI method that increases exponentially with the number of datasets and their sizes. We were unable to conduct linkage experiments using the NAI method for larger p𝑝p and dataset sizes due to its exponential complexity (and thus some data points for the NAI method are missing in Figure 5 (c)).

Figure 5 (d) shows the number of candidate sets to be compared and classified using our AM-CBF approach. The number of candidate sets with the NAI method grows exponentially with the size of the datasets for increasing p𝑝p, as can be seen when p=10𝑝10p=10. In Figures 5 (e) and (f), we compare the complexity requirements of the SEQ and RBR methods with different ring sizes based on rmsubscript𝑟𝑚r_{m} on the NCVR-10,000 datasets for p=10𝑝10p=10 parties. We evaluated the SEQ method with rm=[2,3,4,5]subscript𝑟𝑚2345r_{m}=[2,3,4,5] and the RBR method with rm=[3,4,5]subscript𝑟𝑚345r_{m}=[3,4,5] (rm≥3subscript𝑟𝑚3r_{m}\geq 3 in RBR). This provides ring sizes of [2,2,2,2,2], [3,3,4], [4,6], and [5,5] for rm=2subscript𝑟𝑚2r_{m}=2, 333, 444, and 555, respectively. As shown in the figures, the complexity increases with larger ring sizes, because larger ring sizes mean more comparisons are required in each ring.

We compare the runtime required by our approach (with SEQ) with the baseline approaches on the NCVR-10,000 and 50,000 datasets in Figure 6 (a). Though the baseline approaches require lower runtime for linking p≤5𝑝5p\leq 5 datasets than our approach (because the matches identified in one ring need to be compared again with the candidate sets in the other rings in our approach), they are not scalable to more parties (p>5𝑝5p>5) and larger datasets. We were unable to conduct experiments for AM-BF with p>7𝑝7p>7 and EM-BF with p>5𝑝5p>5 on the NCVR-50,000 datasets due to the exponential increase in the number of candidate sets generated. As can be seen in Figure 6 (a), our approach is scalable and requires significantly lower runtime for linking p=7𝑝7p=7 and 101010 datasets compared to the baseline approaches.

As shown in Figure 6 (b), our approach outperforms the baseline EM-BF and AM-BF approaches in terms of linkage quality measured by F-measure. The filtering approach used in AM-BF results in lower F-measure compared to our approach. The F-measure is high on the non-modified datasets (0% corruption), while it drops with p𝑝p on the modified (20% and 40%) datasets as the number of missed true matches increases when records are modified in each dataset. However, our AM-CBF approach achieves the highest F-measure on both modified and non-modified datasets (though EM-BF performs equally well on the non-modified datasets).

Finally, we compared the DR measures of privacy for our approach based on CBF masking with baseline approaches based on BF masking in Figures 6 (c) and (d). The results show that the DR measures with our approach are consistently lower (and thus privacy is higher) than the baseline approaches. As expected, the DR measures also decrease with larger p𝑝p (as discussed in Section 6.2), and with more corruptions in the dataset because corrupted records reduce the probability of mapping to matching global values in 𝐆𝐆\mathbf{G} to allow the records to be re-identified.

8 Related Work

Various techniques have been proposed in the literature tackling the problem of PPRL [43]. However, most of them consider linking two databases only, and a only few approaches have been proposed for PPRL on multiple databases.

An SMC-based approach using an oblivious transfer protocol was proposed by O’Keefe et al. [23] for PPRL on multiple databases. While provably secure, the approach only performs exact matching of masked values (i.e. variations and errors in the QIDs are not considered) and it is computationally expensive compared to efficient perturbation-based privacy techniques, such as BFs and k𝑘k-anonymity [43]. A multi-party k𝑘k-anonymity-based PPRL approach was introduced by Kantarcioglu et al. [12]. In their apporach, a secure equi-join (exact matching) is applied on the k𝑘k-anonymized databases by a L​U𝐿𝑈LU to identify matching records.

A multi-party PPRL approach for approximate matching of categorical values was proposed by Mohammed et al. [22], where a top-down generalization is performed to provide k𝑘k-anonymous privacy and the generalized blocks are then classified into matches and non-matches using the C4.5 decision tree classifier. Another efficient multi-party approach for categorical data was recently proposed by Karapiperis et al. [14] using a Count-Min sketch data structure. Sketches are used to summarize the local set of elements which are then intersected to provide a global synopsis using homomorphic operations, secure summation, and symmetric noise addition privacy techniques.

As described in Section 7.1, Lai et al. [17]’s approach uses efficient Bloom filter encoding for masking string data in multi-party PPRL. However, the approach performs only exact matching. This approach has been adapted by Vatsalan and Christen [39, 40] for approximate matching in multi-party PPRL (as described in detail in Section 7.1). Several approximate comparison functions for calculating similarities of pairs of string and other data types have been proposed for PPRL by adapting existing comparison functions.

A secure version of the Levenshtein edit distance was proposed by Karakasidis and Verykios [13] using CBFs, where the elements of a string are checked against a CBF of another string to count the number of edits, while the CBF also provides the length of the string masked into it. However, developing privacy-preserving comparison functions for multiple (more than two) values has only recently been considered by Vatsalan and Christen [39, 40] using the Dice coefficient similarity.

Scalability has been addressed by using private blocking functions and / or filtering approaches [43, 44] as well as by parallelizing and / or distributing the tasks among several nodes or parties [15, 44]. The scalability problem in multi-party PPRL has only recently been focused on. Ranbaduge et al. [27, 28] proposed a family of efficient tree-based private blocking techniques for multi-party PPRL using BF encoding and secure summation. Several filtering approaches have been used in PPRL of two sources, including length filtering in BFs [38] and PPJoin techniques [35]. The recently proposed multi-party BF-based PPRL approach [39, 40] (described above) employs a filtering approach based on the similarity of segments of BFs. However, the number of comparisons required for multi-party linkage remains very large even with existing private blocking and filtering approaches employed [27, 39]. Therefore, efficient multi-party filtering and communication patterns need to be developed in order to make PPRL scalable and viable in practical applications.

Several query tree representations have been used for optimizing multi-way join queries [20, 31]. Schneider and DeWitt [31] studied query processing plans with different types of structures, left-deep, right-deep, and bushy. Left-deep and right-deep trees use a base table as the inner and outer operand, respectively, of each join in the plan, while in bushy trees both inputs to a join may themselves result from joins. However, these techniques have not been used for efficient processing of multi-party PPRL.

9 Conclusion

We have presented an efficient and scalable protocol for PPRL of multiple databases with two improved communication patterns. Our approach performs approximate matching on the QID values (of string data) masked using efficient and simple privacy techniques, counting BFs and secure summation. Experiments conducted on real datasets showed the efficiency and scalability of our approach compared to two baseline approaches while achieving superior results in terms of linkage quality and privacy.

In future work, we plan to investigate other improved communication patterns, collision resistant secure summation protocols, and different approximate string comparison functions [2] to be incorporated. We also aim to develop efficient PPRL techniques for identifying matching record sets within sub-sets of parties, which is an important research problem.

Another research direction would be to develop multi-party PPRL approaches under other adversary models such as the covert model [1] or accountable computing [11] (where honest parties can verify fake data from dishonest parties with high probability) to overcome the limitations of the semi-honest (HBC) adversary model. Finally, we plan to investigate improved classification techniques for multi-party PPRL including relational clustering and graph-based approaches [2] which are successfully used in non-PPRL applications.
